contextId.information: This is the reason that God will not listen to their prayers. The blood likely refers to violence that they have done against people. AT: "because it is like your hands are covered with the blood of those you have harmed" or "because you are guilty of violence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: your hands are full of blood

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "branch" is a synecdoche that represents the crops Yahweh will cause to grow in the land of Israel. AT: "Yahweh will cause the crops in Israel to be beautiful" or 2) "branch" is a metaphor that refers to the Messiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the branch of Yahweh will be beautiful

contextId.information: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. AT: "I have seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: my eyes have seen

contextId.information: The author speaks as if the kings were the armies they led. AT: "Rezin ... and Pekah ... led their armies up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Rezin ... and Pekah ... went up

contextId.information: Here "Rezin" represents his army. AT: "Therefore, Yahweh will bring Rezin and his army against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Therefore Yahweh will raise up against him Rezin, his adversary

contextId.information: Here the word "I" refers to the king of Assyria. He was the leader of the Assyrian army and took credit for what the army did at his command. AT: "my army has removed the boundaries of the peoples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I have removed the boundaries of the peoples

contextId.information: "I and my army have brought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I have brought

contextId.information: The earth is pictured as if it has four corners, and those corners are its most distant places. This refers to everywhere on earth where those people might be. AT: "from even the most distant places of the earth" or "from all over the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: from the four corners of the earth

contextId.information: This represents the Assyrian king and his army. AT: "the king of Assyria and his army" or "the Assyrian army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the Assyrian

contextId.information: Ephraim was the largest tribe in Israel. Here it represents the entire northern kingdom of Israel. AT: "Strong cities will disappear from Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Fortified cities will disappear from Ephraim

contextId.information: Here "eyes" represents the people who look. AT: "they will look" or "the people will look" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: their eyes will look

contextId.information: Here "pit" and "snare" represent all the different bad things that will happen to people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the pit, and the snare ... caught in the snare

contextId.information: Here "spirit" represents the speaker as a whole. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: my spirit within me seeks you earnestly

contextId.information: Here "one" refers to a mighty king who also represents his powerful army. AT: "the Lord sends a king with his powerful army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the Lord sends one who is mighty and strong

contextId.information: Here "lips" and "tongue" represent the foreigners who speak a different language than the Israelites do. It is implied that this refers to the Assyrian army that will attack Israel. AT: "Yahweh will speak to this people through enemy soldiers who will speak a foreign language" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: with mocking lips and a foreign tongue he will speak to this people

contextId.information: Here the people are referred to by their "hands" the emphasize that they made something with their hands. AT: "that you have sinned by making with you own hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: that your own hands have sinfully made

contextId.information: This refers the audience by their "eyes." AT: "You will see ... you will behold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Your eyes will see ... they will behold

contextId.information: This refers to the audience by their "hearts." "The terror" refers to their war with the Assyrians. This can be stated clearly. AT: "You will remember the terror that the Assyrians caused you when they attacked." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Your heart will recall the terror

contextId.information: The words "weak hands" and "knees that shake" represent a person who is fearful. AT: "Strengthen those whose hands are weak and whose knees shake from fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Strengthen the weak hands, and steady the knees that shake.

contextId.information: "The deaf" refers to people who cannot hear. They are referred to by their "ears" to emphasize their healing. AT: "deaf people will hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the ears of the deaf will hear

contextId.information: This refers to people who cannot speak.  They are referred to by their "tongues" to emphasize their healing. AT: "mute people will sing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the mute tongue will sing

contextId.information: Sennacherib's army attached the cities. AT: "Sennacherib and his army ... attacked all the fortified cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Sennacherib ... attacked all the fortified cities

contextId.information: Here the king of Assyria is referring to his army as himself. AT: "until my army comes and takes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: until I come and take

contextId.information: These men destroyed the cities listed by conquering them with their armies. Here the word "fathers" refers to his father and his other ancestors who were kings. AT: "that my fathers destroyed with their armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: that my fathers destroyed

contextId.information: Here the messengers are referred to by their "hand" to emphasize that they personally gave it to the king. AT: "that the messengers gave him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: from hand of the messengers

contextId.information: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. AT: "they came ... they will not enter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: he came ... he will not enter

contextId.information: Here Sennacherib refers to both him and his army. They all left Israel and returned home to Assryia. Sennacherib returned to the city Nineveh. AT: "Sennacherib and his army left Israel and went home, and Sennacherib stayed in Nineveh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Sennacherib king of Assyria left Israel and went home and stayed in Nineveh

contextId.information: The word "voice" represents the person who cries out. AT: "Someone cries out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: A voice cries out

contextId.information: The word "mouth" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "for Yahweh has spoken it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it

contextId.information: Here the word "hearts" represent the minds and thoughts of the people. AT: "they cannot understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: their hearts cannot perceive

contextId.information: The words "knee" and "tongue" represent the people. AT: "Every person will kneel before me, and everyone will swear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: To me every knee will bend, every tongue will swear

contextId.information: "Mouth" refers to someone speaking. AT: "I spoke these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: they came out from my mouth

contextId.information: Here "bread" represents food in general. This can be written in positive form. AT: "nor will he be without food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: nor will he lack bread

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the word "one" here to refer to all of the oppressed people. AT: "you oppressed people and drunken people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you oppressed one and drunken one

contextId.information: Here the word "bread" represents food in general. It is implied that the people were buying things to eat that were not really food. AT: "for things to eat that are not really food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: for what is not bread

contextId.information: Here "year" refers to a specific time appointed by Yahweh for restoring Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the year for my redemption

contextId.information: "Bones" refers to the whole body as a part of it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: your bones will sprout

contextId.information: "Sword" is one weapon that represents all of warfare and killing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: with his sword
